She is a merchant selling catalogue merchandise like perfume and cosmetics to help her husband cover household expenses since he works in a small banana farm he owns and income generated is low.

The loan will be of great help for the member since she will invest it in the purchase of merchandise since she has many pending orders this Christmas season and it will also allow her to increase family income and improve her and her husband’s quality of life. Her goal is that her business grows enough so that her husband can stop working on the banana plantation and help her with sales since he’s ill.

This group has a total of 11 members who carry out a variety of activities in animal husbandry and commerce and will be using their loans to buy merchandise and raw materials.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics.

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en: On the table seen above, Abigail has some pineapples and watermelons displayed. She sells different kinds of fruits at Ayensudu near Elmina.  She is married and has 3 children. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy other kinds of fruits to sell. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy other kinds of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beauty products.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en:
Although she has received no formal education, Araba is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling personal care products, such as lotions and soaps, in Ohiaba (near Cape Coast). Araba is married and has five children. Her husband works as a fisherman. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. 

Araba will use this loan to purchase increased amounts of personal care products, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. She will use the new profits from her expanded business to further diversify the type of products that she sells, thereby adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of personal care products to improve overall sales.

loans.name: Missmahu2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MISSMAHU2 est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. Jérémie, le représentant du groupe (celui qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 39 ans est marié à une marchande nommé Nathalie. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont certains scolarisés et tous à leur charge. Jérémie vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Les différentes charges de ménage sont supportées par Jérémie et son femme. Jérémie n'a pas fréquenté l’école mais a appris la soudure, activité qu'il exerce depuis treize ans dans son atelier, ce qui lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Jérémie s’approvisionne dans une ville du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire sa clientèle, Jérémie sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MISSMAHU2 un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les crédits antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter des machines.

loans.name: Development Group

texts.en: Evelyne a thirty year old woman is a married mother of two children. She lives in Masindi district where she runs a retail shop that sells general merchandise such as sugar, cooking oil, batteries, toothpaste among other items. After getting savings from fishing, she started up the business to support her family and ensure education of her children.Evelyne wants to use the loan for buying more soap,toothpaste,sugar for sell. She has a number of customers because of her customary language, and her clients describe her as a honest business woman. Evelyne's dream is to buy land so as to set up houses for rent but she faces a problem of inadequate capital.She is a member of Development group where they guarantee each other to acquire a loan.

loans.use: to buy more soap,toothpaste ,sugar and others for sell

loans.name: Fransisco

texts.en:
Francisco lives in the city of Villa de Garcia located in the State of Nuevo Leon. He is married and has two children. Some time ago he decided to set up his own automotive paint and detailing shop; prior to this he worked for an automotive company but his salary was not enough to cover the cost of his children’s tuition fees. With his business, Francisco has been able to provide his children with an education. His dream is to see his kids successfully finish their education and therefore ensure an opportunity for them for a better future.

One of his children is now helping him out in the shop, and with his help and with the support of the rest of his family Francisco has struggled to come out on top. But now he needs a loan of $650 for the purchase of paint and other materials and so to be able to offer a better variety of colors and services to his clients, and further earning more clients. He and his family need your support. Do not leave them alone. They sincerely thank you for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Francisco vive en la localidad de Villa de García, ubicada en el Estado de Nuevo León, es casado y tiene dos hijos. Hace tiempo que el decidió poner su propio taller de enderezado y pintura, pues anteriormente era empleado de una empresa automotriz, pero no completaba con el sueldo que ganaba, ya que sus hijos se encuentran estudiando y no completaba para las colegiaturas. Con esta actividad Francisco ha podido brindarle a sus hijos lo que requieren para su educación, el principal sueño de el es ver a sus hijos terminar satisfactoriamente sus estudios y de esta manera poder brindarles la oportunidad de un mejor futuro.

Ahora su hijo ya es ayudante del taller, con su apoyo y el de el resto de la familia, Francisco ha luchado para salir adelante, pero el ahora necesita de un crédito de $650 DLLS para poder comparar pintura y material y de esta manera ofrecer una mayor variedad de colores y un mejor servicio, obteniendo así más clientes. El y su familia necesitan de tu apoyo, no los dejes solos, ellos agradecen tu ayuda sinceramente.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Tapdig

texts.en:
This 37-year-old man lives in Salyan region, Yenikand village. He is married and has 2 children. 7 years ago he started this business. He is a responsible man. Tapdig wishes to see his children successfully finish their education and ensure an opportunity for them for a better future.
Now he needs a loan of $700 to buy a pregnant cow.

loans.use: To buy  a pregnant cow

loans.name: Phun

texts.en: A 36-year-old mother of 4 children who are in school, Phun N. lives with her husband in Preyveng Province, Cambodia. She and her husband sell ice on a roadside of this village and typically generate an average of about $5/day in revenue. In order to run this business properly, Phun N. is asking for $1000 in loan funds in order to purchase two ice boxes so that she can keep ice cool for a whole day. Because her husband is a talented mechanic, she hopes to save enough money to open a mechanic shop for her husband in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase two ice boxes to run a business

loans.name: Nidia Guadalupe

texts.es:
Nidia is 26 years old, married, with 1 child. Her husband is an electrician. She owns a beauty salon where she treats women of her community: hair cuts, manicures, and make-up for social events. She will invest the loan in the purchase of beauty products. She belongs to the group "Jastic 4" together with Mrs. Maria Candelaria Hernández López (door-to-door sales of tamales) and Mrs. Ana Isabel Valencia Díaz (food sales). They will invest their loans in kitchen utensils and raw products to make their products.

Translated by Ramón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer

Original description in Spanish:

NIDIA tiene 26 años, casada, un hijo, su esposo es electricista. Ella una estética en donde atiende a las mujeres de su localidad cortándoles el cabello, arreglo de uñas, y maquillándolas para los eventos sociales, con el préstamo invertirá en la compra de productos de belleza. Pertenece al grupo Jastic 4 junto con doña Maria Candelaria Hernández López (venta de tamales casa por casa) y doña Ana Isabel Valencia Díaz (venta de comida). Ellas dos invertirán su préstamo en utensilios de cocina y materia prima para elaborar sus productos.

loans.use: Beauty salon

loans.name: Ni Ketut Desih

texts.id:
Food stall business has been Ni Ketut Desih preoccupation since one year. At 60, she is still productive. So is her husband, who works as a tenant farmer. From her 8 children, only one is still under their resposibility, finishing highschool. The other seven already have their own family. The food stall she rents for Rp5000.00/day. She starts to sell from 1:00 PM to 7:00PM. Distance between her home to the foodstall is about 50 meters. Sales per day is about Rp200,000.00 (about US$22). After expenses her net profit are about Rp50,000.00 ($5.50)/day. Although they are growing old, they do not want to be a burden to their children. This business besides tenant farming are their hope.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha warung makan ini baru ditekuni Ni Ketut Desih setahun yang lalu. Di usianya yang 60 tahun dia masih produktif. Demikian pula suaminya. Suaminya bekerja sebagai petani. Dari 8 anak yang dimilikinya, hanya satu yang masih menjadi tanggungannya – tamat SMA. Ketujuh anak lainnya sudah berkeluarga. Warung makan yang dipakai dia kontrak dengan Rp 5.000,00 per harinya. Dia mulai berjualan pukul 13.00 Wita – 19.00 Wita. Jarak rumah dengan warung makannya kurang lebih 50 m. Dalam sehari dia dapat memperoleh Rp 200.000,00. Setelah dipotong modal, keuntungan bersihnya sekitar Rp 50.000,00. Memang dia dan suaminya sudah menjadi tua, akan tetapi mereka tidak mau menjadi tanggungan bagi anak – anak mereka. Usaha ini harapan mereka, selain menjadi petani.

loans.use:
To buy rice, vegetables, fish and meat

Membeli beras, sayuran, ikan, dan daging.

loans.name: Stop Group

texts.pt:
The Stop Group was formed in July of this year by two ladies: Primavera and Arminda. Primavera is the group leader and she is divorced - her former husband left her to live with another woman. She has three children and she joined the program right after she became a single mother. She did so in order to support her children for they are still in school. Arminda is married and has 7 children. She sells vegetables she grows in her smallholding along with her husband. Her children help out as well when they are not in school. She works at the smallholding in the mornings and she sells vegetables and peanuts in the local market in the afternoons. Arminda was part of a different group but decided to leave it and create the Stop Group alongside Primavera because of the hardship her friend was facing. Primavera lives in Maxixe and sells coconuts in Maputo. She needs to rent a vehicle too haul her coconuts from Maxixe to Maputo.

Translated from Portuguese by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

O grupo Stop foi formado em Julho deste ano e e formado por duas senhoras nomeadamente Primavera e Arminda. Primavera e a lider do Grupo e e divorciada. O marido abandonou-a e foi viver com outra mulher.Ela tem 3 filhos. Ela entrou para o programa assim que o marido a abandonou. Ela entrou para o programa para poder sustentar os seus filhos que ainda sao pequenos e ainda estao a estudar.Arminda e casada e mae de 7 filhos. Ela vende vegetais que colhe de sua machamba onde ela e o marido trabalham.Os filhos quando nao vao a escola tambem ajudam nos trabalhos da machamba. Nas manhas ela trabalha na machamba e nas tardes no mercado para a venda dos vegetais e amendoim. Arminda estava num outro grupo, mas quando Primavera quis entrar para o programa ela resolveu sair do anterior grupo e formar o grupo stop com Primavera que estava passando por um momento dificil na sua vida.Primavera vive na Maxixe mas vende coco em Maputo. Para tal ela precisa alugar uma viatura para transportar o coco de Maxixe para Maputo.

loans.use: The members of this group want to use the money to purchase and transport coconuts and other crops grown in a smallholding to the local market and also to purchase more seeds.

loans.name: Maria Marcia

texts.es:
Mrs. María belongs to the communal bank “Mujeres Virtuosas” (“Virtuous Women”) and lives in the Calleria district. She is 37 years old, is married, and has 4 children one of whom works in the capital city of Lima. The other three children still depend greatly on her. Her husband is a merchant, however his earnings do not meet their living expenses. So, with her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos, María decided to invest in the purchase and sale of shoes, sandals and baby clothes.

Currently María has her location in the Market #2, where she sells her products. She rises early in the morning to fix breakfast for her children and husband, she takes the children to school, fixes lunch, and attends to her business in the afternoons. At night, she rests and shares happy times with her family.

With the loan of 2,000 soles, to be repaid in six months, she will buy several dozen each of assorted items such as shoes, diapers, baby clothes, tops and pants, towels, dresses, etc. María feels good that to date she has grown her business with each loan, and likes collaborating with Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María, pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Virtuosas, vive en el Jr. Independencia 759 del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 37 años de edad, es casada, tiene 4 hijos, uno de ellos trabaja en la cuidad de Lima, y tres aún dependen mucho de ella, su esposo es comerciante, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza, es así que María, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00, decide invertir en la compra y venta de zapatos, sandalias, y ropitas de bebes. Actualmente María, tiene su puesto de venta en el mercado Nº 2 donde vende sus productos. Se levanta temprano para preparan el desayuno de sus hijos y esposo, luego lleva a la escuela a sus hijos, prepara el almuerzo y en las tardes atiende su negocio. En las noches descansa y comparte momentos de alegría con sus hijos y esposo. Con el préstamo de S/. 2.000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará diez docenas de zapatos, diez docenas de pañales, diez docenas de ropitas de bebe, polos, pantalones, colchas, ropones, ajuares, toallas, vestidos, canguros y bolsos. María, se siente muy bien hasta el momento, está incrementando su negocio con cada préstamo, se siente muy a gusto trabajando con Manuela Ramos porque le da todas las facilidades del caso y se siente una mujer realizada en todos los sentidos.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise (shoes, diapers, baby clothes, tops and pants, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more fruit for re-sale and help his wife's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy an extra table and chair, cooking oil, a cooler box, fish, transport, and the municipal permit to operate her business

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana Maria is a member of the Comunal Bank Las Ucayalinas, located on Maria Parado D. Bellido Street 171, in the District of Manatay, Department of Ucayali. She is 63 years old, has 8 children, and her husband is a laborer. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in a small general store. Currently her general store is well-stocked with different types of products. She runs the business with the help of her children, and they distribute the domestic chores amongst themselves. At night she enjoys spending time with her children. With this loan of 1,500 soles, which will be repaid over 4 months, she will buy rice, sugar, milk, soft drinks, bags for her lollipops, noodles, preserves, etc. Ana Maria is a tough woman who likes to work in order to get her family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ana María pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Ucayalinas, ubicado en Jr. María Parado D. Bellido 171, del Distrito D. Manantay del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 63 años es madre D. 8 hijos, su esposo es obrero. Con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidiD. invertirlo en una pequeña bodega. En la actualidad su bodega esta mas implementada con diferentes tipos D. productos, con la ayuda D. sus hijos atienD. el negocio, se distribuyen las tareas domesticas y por las noches le gusta compartir un momento agradable con sus hijos . Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,500, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprara arroz, azúcar, leche, gaseosas, bolsitas para sus chupetes, fideos, conservas, etc. Ana Maria es una mujer luchadora que le gusta trabajar para poder sacar a su familia adelante.

loans.use: Purchase products for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand a bricklaying business

loans.name: Enedelia

texts.es:
Enedelia is a married mother of 2 children, ages 27 and 26. She started her business 3 years ago, initially selling used clothing by bulk in the markets of Salinas, Ciénaga de Flores and Zuazua. She set up this business in order to get ahead in life and to support her husband with the household expenses.

She is now requesting a loan of $500 USD, which she will repay in 6 months, so that she can stock up on shoes for the season and offer a wider selection of merchandise to her customers. This will be possible with your support.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Enedelia es casada y tiene dos hijos de 27 y 26 años, empezó su negocio desde hace 3 años, inicio vendiendo ropa usada de paca en los mercados de Salinas, Ciénaga de Flores y Zuazua, ella empezó con el negocio para salir adelante y apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.

Ahora solicita un crédito por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para surtir zapatos de temporada y tener más variedad de mercancía para así ofrecerla a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda esto será posible.

loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria is a humble mother who, with much effort, works on her potato farm to later sell its agricultural products in the markets of the closest towns or to traders from the same area. Her responsibilities as a mother have encouraged her to pursue farming activities to continue growing the best vegetables in the area. However, she wants to increase her investment in agriculture and expand her farmland to improve the living standards of her beloved family.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer.

GREGORIA, es una humilde madre de familia que con mucho esfuerzo hace trabajar sus terrenos de cultivo de papa para luego vender sus productos agrícolas en los mercados de las ciudades más cercanas o a los comerciantes desde su misma zona.El tener muchas responsabilidades como madre de familia le ha incentivado a seguir adelante en su actividad como agricultora para seguir produciendo los mejores vegetales de la zona.Pero ella quiere aumentar su inversión en la agricultura y ampliar sus terrenos de cultivo para mejorar el nivel de vida de su amada familia.

loans.use: Increased capital to improve the farming of vegetables

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 24 year old mother of two children. She lives with her ifamily in the Dunga slums of Kisumu. Sarah, who runs a vegetable stall, requests US $600 to purchase more stock of vegetables.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase stock of vegetables

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-year-old Grace M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two young children. Additionally she supports a young relative who boards with her while she attends school in Dar.

Grace owns a video store that she runs with the assistance of her husband. In addition to renting out movie videos to customers, they also work as videographers. At occasions like weddings and birthdays, Grace and her husband are available to record your special occasion for posterity!

Grace currently makes monthly profits of US$ 110 from her video store. This is her second loan with SELFINA; she successfully paid back her initial loan of US$ 50 which has allowed her to request a far larger loan this time around. Grace would like US$ 350 to purchase new video cameras and blank tapes. She is hopeful that this will enable her to expand the scale of her business in the near future.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy video cameras and blank tapes for her video store

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene M., 26 years old and single, is a hard-working young woman who has been sewing for three years. She is a specialist in women's and kids' wear. Her skills and designs are in a class by themselves. She sews various kinds of styles that give her customers a new look, like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, kids' wear etc. She also sews children's school uniforms for most of the schools in Obuasi as a subsidiary to give her extra income to support her business.

Irene wants to use the loan to buy supplies of sewing materials like linen, thread, thimbles, and lace materials, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to provide for herself. She is a member of the community group called Divine Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access and repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy supplies of sewing materials to increase her output and efficiency

loans.name: Salamatou

texts.fr:
Madame A. Salamatou est née en 1958 à Gléi localité située à 173Km de la ville de Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de quatre enfants qui vont tous à l’école. Son mari qui est un revendeur n’a pas un revenu stable. C’est ainsi qu’elle l’aide dans les dépenses de la famille surtout le paiement des frais de scolarité de leurs enfants. Elle vend des légumes et des produits de consommation courante à la devanture de sa maison.
Elle a une fois bénéficié du crédit et a bien remboursé. Ce second crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 6 sacs de maïs, 3 sacs du haricot, un panier de légumes et 2 cartons de tomate et de lait afin de pouvoir bien vendre.
texts.en:
Mrs. Salamatou A. was born in 1958 in Gléi, a village located 173 km from Lomé. She is married and the mother of four children, all attending school. Her husband who is a retailer does not have a stable income. Thus she is helping him with the family's expenses and above all with the children's school fees. She sells vegetables and everyday goods in front of her house. Once she received a loan that she reimbursed fully. The second loan she is requesting would allow her to buy 6 bags of corn, 3 bags of beans, a basket of vegetables and 2 boxes of tomatoes and milk in order to resale them.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of everyday goods

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
Guadalupe tiene 30 años de edad, estudió el sexto grado de primaria, es conviviente, madre de una niña de 2 añitos y vive en el jr. Zapana Nº 325, distrito de Juli, provincia de Chuchito, departamento de Puno.

Es socia del Banco Comunal “Niño San Salvador” de Juli. Con el préstamo de S/.300 compró galletas, chocolates, gelatina, dulces, gaseosas, etc. A los 12 años de edad se inició con su negocio de venta de golosinas en la Plaza de Armas. Le agradó más trabajar y por eso dejó de lado los estudios. Cuando tuvo su esposo continuo vendiendo y ambos comenzaron el negocio de la venta de medicina natural. Desde que integró el banco comunal empezó a vender golosinas en el mirador de Juli, lugar donde llegan bastante turistas que muchas veces le compran sus productos.

Con este préstamo de S/. 600, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará 5 cajas de galletas a S/.78, 5 paquetes de gaseosas a S/. 40, chocolates a S/. 140 y un saco de mana a S/. 40.

Su deseo es construir su casa y seguir con su negocio.
texts.en:
Guadalupe is a 30-year-old woman who completed the sixth grade. She is married and has a 2-year-old daughter. They live on Nº 325 Zapana Street, in the Juli district of the Chuchito province, department of Puno. She is a member of the “Niño San Salvador” microfinance institute in Juli. With the 300.00 PEN loan that she received, she purchased cookies, chocolate, gelatin, candy, soft drinks, etc. At the age of 12, she started her own candy business in the Plaza de Armas. She liked working more than studying, so she left her schooling aside. When she got married, she continued with her business, and then they both started a holistic medicine business. Ever since she joined the microfinance institute, she started selling candy at the scenic viewpoint in Juli, where there are many tourists who often times purchase her products. With this loan of 600.00 PEN, which will be repaid in 4 monthly installments, she will purchase 5 boxes of cookies at 78.50 PEN, 5 crates of soft drinks at 40.00 PEN, chocolate at 140.00 PEN, and a sack of Peruvian marzipan at 40.00 PEN. She wishes to build her own house and continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cookies, soft drinks, chocolate, and Peruvian marzipan

loans.name: Guillermo

texts.es:
Guillermo L. vive en la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz con su esposa, la señora Leandra Quispe de L. y sus dos hijas.
Guillermo es rentista de la policía y su esposa era vendedora en un mercado de la zona.
Debido a su edad avanzada la señora Leandra ya no atiende su puesto, del mismo que se hará cargo su hija. El puesto de venta estuvo sin atención mucho tiempo, por lo que necesita ser refaccionado para poder ser utilizada nuevamente.
El crédito solicitado será para la refacción del puesto de venta en el mercado de la zona.
Esta es la quinta vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado califican favorablemente a Guillermo.
texts.en:
Guillermo L. lives in the Tembladerani zone of the city of La Paz with his wife Leandra Quispe de Lauara and their two daughters.

Guillermo is a retired policeman living on a pension and his wife used to be a vendor in the local market. Due to Leandra's advanced age she can no longer tend her market stall and is turning it over to her daughter. The vending stall has not had attention for quite a while and so needs renovation and repairs in order to make it usable. The loan money will be used for the stall repairs. This is the fifth time Guillermo has asked for a loan and based on the analysis of his socioeconomic position, his loan request has been approved.

Translated from Spanish by Melissa Hays, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vending stall repairs

loans.name: 21 De Mayo Group

texts.es: La asociación “21 de mayo” pertenece al centro focal  Villa Tejada ubicada en la ciudad de El Alto. Dicho grupo trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer hace más de cuatro años. Afirman que el dinero no les alcanza para los gastos domésticos diarios y gastos de alquiler ya que cuentan con numerosas familias. La mayoría de ellas tiene tiendas de barrio donde ofrecen variedad de productos. Con el mayor entusiasmo quieren mejorar sus ventas comprando variedad de productos por cajas, de esta manera generar mayores ganancias que les permita ahorrar para poder comprar una casa propia.
texts.en:
The “21 de mayo” (May 21st) group is based in the Villa Tejada neighbourhood of the city of El Alto. This group has been working in conjunction with Pro-Mujer for more than 4 years. The members of the group tell us that they lack money to pay for their household expenses and the rent for their businesses as they have large families. Most of the members own neighbourhood store which offer a variety of products. They are highly motivated to improve their sales by buying a variety of products in bulk, thereby generating greater profits which will allow them to buy their own homes.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of products for their respective grocery stores.

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en: Doreen D. sells food supplies at the Elmina new market. Doreen has received junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a sawmill operator. Doreen has been selling food supplies since 2000. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more food supplies to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards a house she wants to put up for the children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more food supplies to meet the increase in demand by her customers.

loans.name: Ismoil

texts.en:
A. Ismoil is a very responsible and optimistic person, and he has four children and a wife whom he has to support. Ismoil wishes to develop his business. This business consists of raising cattle in his village because there is a very high demand for milk from villagers and especially from customers who come from enclosed towns. Ismoil is helped by his wife, who is pictured. 

Ismoil is currently faced with many problems because his children are growing, and accordingly, their expenses are growing too. The only way to get out of this difficulty is to succeed in business, so we hope that his capabilities and the services provided by Imon International will help him improve his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war that ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R. further damaged its already weak economy. 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable--conditions that have resulted in high levels of unemployment and forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle

loans.name: Mariluz

texts.es: Mariluz tiene 34 años, hace 6 meses se separó de su pareja, es madre de dos hijos, actualmente vive en su casa propia. Se dedica a la agricultura y también prepara el almuerzo para todos los peones que realizaban la faena de sus cultivos. Desde muy niña aprendió a limpiar sus chacras sacando las malezas (hierbas) con el machete. Ahora prefirió comprar funguicidas para evitar la continuidad de las hierbas que acechan sus plantas, desde entonces ya no realiza con la misma frecuencia el macheteo; pero después de haber esparcido este herbecida cree que la producción de sus platanales ha aminorado, y las hojas se están tornando amarillas por lo que está preocupada y está buscando una solución inmediata para recuperar la producción de sus plátanos. Pero al margen de todas sus dificultades, dice estar muy contenta con sus cultivos y piensa incrementar su producción para tener cosechas alternadas. Mariluz está muy contenta por integrar este banco comunal, y se ha ofrecido en apoyar en las labores de secretaria, del mismo modo se compromete en hacer sus pagos de forma muy puntual. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes para que pueda abonar sus chacras de plátanos, y de ese modo mejorar la producción de sus plantas.
texts.en:
Mariluz is 34 years old. Six months ago she separated from her husband. She is the mother of two children. She currently lives in her own house. She works in agriculture and also prepares lunch for the laborers that cultivate her farm. Since she was a little girl, she learned to weed her farm using a machete. Recently, she bought herbicides in order to kill the weeds that threaten her plants. Since then, she hasn’t use the machete as much, but after having applied the herbicide, she believes that the production of her banana plants has slowed, and the leaves are turning yellow. She is worried about this and is looking for an immediate solution to restore the production of her bananas. Despite all her difficulties, she is very happy with her farm and is considering increasing her productions so that she can grow alternate crops. Mariluz is very happy to be a part of this community bank. She has offered to help as a secretary, and also pledges to make her payments on time. The money that she requests is in order for her to buy fertilizers so that she can maintain her plots of bananas and, in this way, improve the production of her plants.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her plants

loans.name: Afusat

texts.en: Afusat sells  bags of charcoal. She is 52 years old and married with five children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. Afusat has been in this business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Rina

texts.en:
Rina B., 27, is a barbecue stick vendor and lives with her husband, Mario, a van dispatcher, in Tuguegarao City. Rina wants to improve her small business to assist her husband in earning a living, especially to send her children to school. The couple has two children: R-Jay, 6, and Raechelle, 5, both of whom study in the elementary level. Rina says her family lives a simple yet happy life in the community. She and her husband are striving hard to improve their poor living condition. 

Her income from vending is just enough to meet her family’s daily needs. She is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 to improve her business and save for her children’s education. Along with barbecue sticks, she also wants to sell different snacks. She is planning to cook and sell banana cue (fried banana coated with sugar), rice cakes and other easy-to-make snacks. She hopes to maintain and develop her enterprise in the future by working hard and by committing everything to the Lord.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria A. lives in a rural area of Dummon Quezon, Isabela. She describes their place as mountainous and they have rough road conditions. She has three children; two have already graduated from college and the youngest, unfortunately wasn't able to finish high school. 

Maria A. maintains a typical village store in their simple village and she is hoping to take out a loan from ASKI amounting to PHP 15,000 to have an additional working capital for her store. She hopes to improve her store by purchasing more products and to add stock to be able to minimize time and fare consumption going to and from the market of Roxas, Isabela. With the lenders financial support, she will be able to prosper despite their poor living situation and to earn more profit from her business.

loans.use: buy more stock for her store

loans.name: Ven

texts.en:
Ven S., 35, is a domestic rice trader. She owns a rice-mill in her home which she uses to hull rice to earn a profit. She usually goes to buy rice in bulk from people who live in rural area, then stores the rice in her home for sale or hulling. Her husband (pictured), works with her in hulling rice as well as buying and selling oxen for earning additional profit. Most of their customers are village rice farmers.

Because this is the rice-harvesting season, Ven S. hopes to buy rice to store in order to resell it later to gain income but she is lacking capital. That is why she has decided to request a loan from Kiva's partner HKL.

loans.use: To buy rice to store

loans.name: Melgin

texts.en:
Melgin S. is from the town of Migcanaway Tangub City. She is 27 years old. Melgin is married and has 3 infant children. To make a living, Melgin owns & operates a transportation business. This business involves operating boat-ride services. Melgin has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melgin joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Melgin is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Melgin from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and to support her family's needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle for better transportation service.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Rosario, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Paz II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 34 años, 03 hijos pequeños que aun dependen de ella.

Su carácter emprendedor y el amor a su familia le motivaron a iniciar su propio negocio, junto con su esposo brindando el servicio de movilidad, que poco a poco fueron aumentando y ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad. 
 
En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio de movilidad, tiene sus clientes fijos que a diario les brinda el servicio. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, invertirá comprando 02 llantas, como repuestos nuevos, para su motokar. Parte del Dinero también lo invertirá comprando.

Rosarito, desea seguir adelante y cumplir sus sueños y metas, porque es una mujer que cuando se propone algo lo cumple. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos,  por ayudarla a contribuir con sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Sra. Rosario belongs to the La Paz II community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of San Martin. She is 34 years old, partnered and has 3 young children still in her care.

Her enterprising nature and love for her family led her to start her own taxi business, a business that she operates with her husband. They've been adding to the business bit by bit and gaining experience at this particular line of work. She's still in business and now has a regular set of customers for whom she provides service.

With the loan of S/.1,500 [1,500 soles], she will buy 2 tires, for spares, for her "motokar". [Parte del Dinero tambien lo invertira comprando.]

Rosarito wants to continue pushing ahead, fulfilling her dreams and meeting her goals, because she is a woman who knows what she wants and goes and gets it. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos movemento for helping her with her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two tires for motokar business.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en: Sauda S. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and business woman. She runs a café as a food vendor at Yombo Kiwalani Ward in Dar es Salaam. She also sells soft drinks to customers. She has three school children and she manages to pay their school fees from the business income. She has also managed to purchase a building site. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Oluwaseun

texts.en: Oluwaseun O. is 32 years old and married with 2 children. She sells medicine and provisions. She is requesting a loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more medicine and provisions to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
61-year-old Asuncion and her 65-year-old husband, who is a farmer, started growing rice as a business when Asuncion inherited a piece of agricultural land from her parents seven months ago. And timely to that, Asuncion had known Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) as being the microfinance organization that lends money to women who aspire to become entrepreneurs.

Asuncion’s first loan was used to finance her rice production business. After four months, the rice was harvested and she saw that it produced profit well, and enough to finance the next season of planting.

However, Asuncion wants her business to grow. She wants to produce a hybrid quality of rice and to build her own storage room where she can store her rice after harvest. Through borrowing a larger amount from ASHI she believes that someday she will be able to finance a greater area of rice field and be able to hire laborers in their community to work on her farm.

Asuncion’s two children, who have their own source of income now, also help her during the rice planting and harvesting seasons.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seedlings for her farm

loans.name: Marisol Lina

texts.es:
La señora Marisol Lina posee su propia pulpería la cual fundó desde hace cinco años en el departamento de León específicamente en el municipio de Telica donde a diario oferta los productos comestibles, los productos personales, entre otros.

Hoy en día en vistas a la necesidad de suplir sus estantes con productos, el apoyo lo busca en Ceprodel solicitando un crédito para la compra de los productos y de esta manera continuar mejorando su condición en el establecimiento y a su vez satisfacer a los clientes de la pulpería.
texts.en:
Mrs. Marison Lina has her own food store, which she founded 5 years ago in the León state, specifically in the town of Telica. There, she daily offers food and personal care products, among other things.

Lately, seeing the necessity to supply the shelves with products she seeks support at Ceprodel, requesting a loan that will be used to buy products. This way, she can continue to improve her establishment conditions, as well as to satisfy her customers.


Translated from Spanish by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 43-year-old married man and father of 4 children. He has owned a car repair shop since 2004 and has 15 years of experience in this field. Today, Ahmad is requesting to borrow $1,000 to renovate his shop in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: to renovate his shop

loans.name: Maria Elsa

texts.es: La señora Maria Elsa C. García , tiene la edad de 37 años , habita en el barrio la Francia numero dos , junto a su esposo , el cual trabaja como albañil y le apoya con los gastos del hogar , ellos tiene a su cargo dos hijos , uno de 13 y otro de 14 , los cuales trabajan  en la simbra unas horas por la mañana y luego al colegio , los planes hacia su familia es poder darle una mejor bienestar a su hijos , desde hace cuatro años se dedica ala actividad agrícola , inicio con sus propios esfuerzos , sus sueños es poder establecer una manzana de piña . El financiamiento lo quiere para la compra de insumos y fertilizantes y poder mejorar la simbra. Que espera vender a buen precio.
texts.en:
Maria Elsa C. García, who is 37 years of age, lives in the Francia Number Two neighborhood with her husband, who works as a bricklayer and assists her with household expenses. They care for two children, one 13 years old and the other 14, who work for a few hours in the morning and then go to school. Their plans for their family include being able to improve their children's well-being. For four years they have been engaged in agriculture, starting the activity with their own efforts. They dream of establishing a pineapple field. The financing that they seek is for the purchase of raw materials and fertilizers to improve their crop sowing. They hope to sell the crop at a good price.

Translated from Spanish by Amanda McDermott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to improve crop planting

loans.name: Maria Carmen

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Nueva Semilla se formó en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad se  caracteriza por los cuatro ríos que bañan la ciudad, sus hábiles artesanos y su suculenta gastronomía atrae a turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

El Bankito Nueva Semilla está conformado por un grupo de mujeres que tienen como objetivo la superación  propia y de su familia mediante la capacitación y su inserción en el desarrollo de  la micro empresa para mejorar su situación económica y su calidad de vida.

La señora María Carmen  A. L. es socia del  Banco Comunal Nueva Semilla, vive en las afueras de la Ciudad de Cuenca en la comunidad el Carmen de Guzho  sector Tierra Blanca, María  tiene 51  años de edad es casada y fruto de su unión  engendró ocho  hijos de 29, 27, 23, 22, 19, 15, 13, 11 años, sus cuatro  primeros hijos ya son casados, y su hija de 19 años pasa en casa ya que sufre de reumatismo con el hijo de trece años que ya no estudia y ayuda en algo con los quehaceres del hogar,  su hijo de 15 años trabaja con ella en la colocación de piso flotante y su último hijo estudia en la escuela José Rafael Arízaga  de la comunidad. Su esposo trabaja en la construcción lo que facilitó para que edifiquen su propia casa.

María se dedica a la cría de  animales como cuyes, chanchos y gallinas, debe distribuir su tiempo con otras actividades como los quehaceres del hogar y en ayudar a su hijo a colocar piso flotante en casas que le contratan.

Nuestra socia  lleva dos años trabajando  en la banca comunal lo que le ha permitido comprar sus animales para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y manifiesta  que el préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR le entregue va a comprar  más  pollos y cuyes que son de rápido crecimiento así como comida y vitaminas.

El sueño de María es ver que sus hijos salgan adelante con el ejemplo que ella les da.
texts.en:
The community bank Nueva Semilla was formed in the city of Cuenca. This city is characterised by the four rivers that bathe the city, its people´s artisanal skills and succulent gastronomy which attracts tourists from Equador and abroad. El Bankito Nueva Semilla is made up of a group of women who share the goal of improving their own situation and that of their family through training and initiation into micro-business development to improve their economic situation and quality of life. María Carmen A. L. is a member of the community bank Nueva Semilla. She lives on the outskirts of Cuenca in the Carmen de Guzho community, located in the Tierra Blanca district. María is 51 years old and married, and the fruit of her marriage has produced eight children of 29, 27, 23, 22, 19, 15, 13 and 11 years of age. Her first four children are already married. Her 19 year old daughter stays at home since she suffers from rheumatism. Her 13 year old son no longer studies but helps her with domestic chores. Her 15 year old son works with her laying laminated floors and her youngest child studies at José Rafael Arízaga community school. Her husband works in construction, which helped them to build their own house. María raises guinea pigs, pigs and hens. She has to spread her time to include other activities such as domestic chores and helping her son to lay laminated floors in the houses where he is contracted. María has spent two years working with the community bank, which has allowed her to buy her animals to help her husband with living costs. She says that she will use the loan that FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR (Foundation of Hope) grants her to buy more chickens and guinea pigs which grow rapidly, as well as food and vitamins. María's dream is to see her children get ahead by the example that she gives them.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more chickens, guinea pigs, food and vitamins

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 44-year-old married man with 4 children. He has owned an oil changing shop since 2006. He has a great demand for his services and thus he wants to borrow $1,000 to buy more oil and renovate his shop in order to serve his clients.

loans.use: Buy more oils and renovate his shop

loans.name: Jesus

texts.es: El señor Jesús A. Ramírez es casado con la señora Claudia Martina Balbuena, son padres de familia de 2 hijos pequeñitos, el labora para un empresa como albañil desde hace 3 años, aparte obtiene ingresos extras ya que realiza trabajos por fuera, porque las personas lo buscan para que les realice construcciones y mejoras en su vivienda. El y su esposa están tramitando este crédito para la ampliación de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Señor Jesús A. Ramírez is married to Señora Claudia Martina Balbuena; they are parents of 2 small children. He has worked for a company as a bricklayer for 3 years, and also earns extra income doing outside jobs, because people look for him to do construction and improvements on their homes. He and his wife are taking out this loan to add on to their house.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to add on to their house

loans.name: Fruit Of Joy Group

texts.en:
Joyce is thirty years old. She is divorced and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people.

She trades in textile materials and clothes. Joyce is the leader of a trust bank group called Fruit of Joy. The members of the group are mainly into fishing and other commercial activities. The group requests for a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Joyce, the group leader, is in the middle of the photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best of education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is married with a grown son. She lives and runs her business in the central market of her home town of Pavlograd. She sells office supplies, household items and other retail items. Her kiosk is located right at the entrance to the marketplace which makes it a favorable spot for many potential customers. Ludmila has been working in this sphere of trade for 5 years. Presently, she has 40,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory. Her net profit amounts to 4,000 - 6,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Ludmila has proved to be a reliable borrower with a stable business. She is always very customer-friendly. This time she is requesting a 15,000 Grivnya loan to purchase additional merchandise for the holiday season. Ludmila owns two vending locations and is hoping to re-stock them with inventory using the current loan.

loans.use: to increase her working capital

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa V. is a vegetable seller. She is 55 years old and lives in Khsom village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Sarin Mom, helps her with the business. Mrs. Channa V. has eight children: five of them are employed in different positions, while the other three are students. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. 
Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Jogilyn

texts.en:
Jogilyn C. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 21 years old and is married.

Jogilyn owns and operates a business providing "habal-habal" services to local community members (a habal-habal is a motorcycle with an extended seat that carries 2-6 passengers), her husband serve as the driver of their motor vehicle. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jogilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI.

Jogilyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Martin Antonio

texts.es:
El Señor Martin Antonio B. M., labora como higienista en el Mercado de Mayoreo de Managua, el tiene cuatro  hijos a su cargo y tres de ellos  se encuentran en edad escolar, esta Casado, ha trabajado once créditos con CEPRODEL durante ocho  años, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido los once créditos en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL,  el es un cliente excelente.
El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: zinc, cemento, arena y mano de obra para reforzar las paredes de su casa de habitación, ya que estas actualmente están muy débiles.
Todo esto con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y  una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.

Martin Antonio dijo que los préstamos otorgados han sido para el mejoramiento de su vivienda.
texts.en:
El Señor Martin Antonio B. M. works as a hygienist in the Mercado de Mayoreo of Managua. He has four children in his care and three of them are school age. He is married. He has had eleven loans from CEPRODEL during eight years; during these years, thanks to financing by CEPRODEL, he has invested the eleven loans in the improvement of his residence. He is an excellent customer. The requested loan will be invested in construction materials such as corrugated metal roofing, cement, and sand and in labor to reinforce the walls of his house. The walls are currently very weak. The objective of all this is to give better security and better living conditions to his children. Martin Antonio said that loans granted had been used to improve his residence.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home Improvement

loans.name: Purificacion

texts.es:
La Sra. Purificación A., tiene dos años de dedicarse al comercio y su actividad principal es la venta de Ropa nueva.- dicha actividad la realiza de manera ambulante y domiciliar.
Doña Purificación sale a vender la mercadería en diferentes comunidades y aldeas circunvecinas al Municipio de Teupasenti, lugar donde casi no tiene competencia, viaja para vender en lugares donde los demás comerciantes es muy raro que lo hagan.  
Ella vende una gran variedad de ropa como ser: Pantalón Jeans de varón y de mujer, blusas, camisas, cameras, sandalias de hule, toallas, ropa interior para ambos sexos, cobijas etc.
necesita el credito para comprar mas mercaderia y asi poder vender mas en los lugares que visita.
las ganancias las necesita para sacar adelante a su familia que es lo mas importante que ella tiene en su vida.
texts.en:
Purificación A. has been a merchant for two years; her main product is new clothing. She sells door-to-door and from home. Purificación goes out to the various neighborhoods and villages surrounding Teupasenti, where she hardly has any competition; she goes to areas where it is rare that other merchants visit. She sells a wide variety of articles of clothing like: jeans for men and women, blouses, shirts, rubber sandals, towels, underwear for both men and women, blankets, etc. She needs funding to buy more merchandise so that she can sell more in the areas she visits. The profits are needed to support her family, who are the most important thing in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, t-shirts, blouses, pajamas, sandals, underwear.

loans.name: Lesbia Maria

texts.es: La señora Lesbia Maria tiene una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación desde hace 30 años. Por lo que siempre ha luchado por mejorar cada día. Este no es el primer financiamiento que ha solicitado, pues han sido muy bien administrado en su negocio. Por lo que su actividad es muy importante para ella. Esta solicitando un nuevo financiamiento para invertirlo en su negocio, ya que se acerca la semana santa y ella requiere comprar más producto al negocio, sus ventas las realiza de contado y al crédito, sus compras las realiza a camiones repartidores y en el mercado oriental. Sueña con mantener activo su negocio que es su principal fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Lesbia Maria has had a grocery store in her home for 20 years; she has striven always to improve daily. This isn't her first loan request; she has administered them in her business very well. Her activity is very important to her. She is asking for new funding to invest in stock for her store because Holy Week is approaching and she needs to buy more stock inventory. She sells both for cash and on credit. She buys her supplies from delivery trucks and in the Oriental market. She dreams with keeping her business active because it's her main source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock merchandise.

loans.name: Luzalva

texts.es:
Lusalva M. D. vive en la ciudadela 20 de Julio de la ciudad de Barranquilla,   sector comercial y  también residencial. Lusalva se dedica a la confección de ropa para niños, necesita un crédito por valor de  $1.500.000, para comprar al por mayor y de contado, materia prima e insumos como telas, cintas encajes e hilos.
Inició su negocio en el año 1990; ella primero estudió modistería en Bucaramanga y trabajó en un taller de confecciones para luego independizarse y en la actualidad  trabaja con su hija que se dedica al corte y otra operaria que trabaja en el acabado de los vestidos y que con su encanto los adorna y decora, al igual que  la señora Susana  que diseña y confecciona en un extensivo horario d e 8:00 a m  a 8:00 P.m.  pues vive enamorada de su arte.
Luzalva M., vende por docenas a clientes de un centro comercial cercano a su taller, llamado Metrocentro y  a clientes varios ubicados en colmenas del centro de Barranquilla, donde  hay una gran competencia pero a ella la prefieren por la calidad en los acabados y su estricto cumplimiento en la entrega. Sus compras las realiza  semanalmente y algunos insumos como los detalles, botones  y adornos cada tres días.

Este es el noveno crédito realizado a  la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización en la tiene 12 años de participación tanto en sus programas de crédito, como los de  capacitación. Estando vinculada a estos procesos  ha logrado modernizar su maquinaria: así fue cuando compró las 2 fileteadores, luego 2 máquinas de coser y también hizo adecuaciones a su apartamento.
Su gran sueño de montar una unidad de comercialización en un centro comercial de prestigio, pero reconoce que debe esperar haciendo esfuerzos mercadologicos, que le ayuden a aumentar la producción y las ventas de ropa de niños para  generar por lo menos un empleo más, ese es precisamente su gran desafío.
texts.en:
Luzalva M. D. lives in Barranquilla’s 20 de Julio housing project, which is both a commercial and residential area. She manufactures children’s clothing and needs a $1.500.000 loan to buy raw materials like fabric, ribbon, lace and thread at wholesale and retail. She started her business in 1990 having learned to be a seamstress in Bucaramanga. She was employed at a tailor shop but later became independent and currently works with her daughter, who does the cutting, and another worker, who does the finishing on the items and who uses her skills to decorate and adorn them, and with Susana who designs and sews; she works a long shift from 8am to 8pm because she adores her art. Luzalva M. sells by the dozen to customers in a shopping center near her shop called, Metrocentro and to customers located in colmenas (densely populated apartment buildings) in downtown Barranquilla. Competition is high but she is preferred thanks to the quality of her finishing and her strict adherence to delivery schedules. She buys most of her raw materials weekly but some of them like, details, buttons and decorations, every three days. This is her 9th loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, an organization she has been collaborating with for 12 years, both in loan programs and in training sessions. Being tied to these processes has made it possible for her to modernize her equipment. This is how she was able to purchase two over lock sewing machines (special sewing machines to do finishing on garments) and do some home improvements to her apartment. Her great dream is to set up a store in a prestigious shopping center but she knows that she must wait and continue to make merchandising efforts that will help her increase production and sales of children’s clothes in order to generate at least one additional job. This is precisely her great challenge.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, lace, ribbon and other sewing supplies and materials.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en: Leah S. M. is married and has four children, aged between 12 and 24 years old. Her business is located in Kakamega, Kenya. She has been selling cereals such as maize, beans, wheat and groundnuts for the last six years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is that there are so many people in the same business in her area and so customers are spoiled by the choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of KES 20,000 to buy more cereals to expand her business. She hopes to enlarge her business and start supplying in bulk. She is very hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to buy maize, beans, etc.

loans.name: La Union 1 Group

texts.en:
Juana, 50, is the coordinator of her group La Union (The Union), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children.

Juana is excited to be taking her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing fabric to make the sheets, curtains and bed covers that she makes and sells. She will use the profits to repair her home as well as support her children in their college education. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Fabric

loans.name: Emilio

texts.es: El Sr. Emilio se dedica al servicio técnico, arreglando televisores, equipos de sonido, microndas, computadoras y todo aparato electrónico, es muy conocido porla zona de San Antonio Bajo que donde vive, es casado y su esposa tiene un restaurante que atiende los sabados y ambos aportan para los gastos de la casa, a su cuidado solo tienen un hijo ya que los otros ya son independientes, el crédito que solicita ahora es para comprar repuestos, es un cliente muy responsable y trabajador se siente orgullosos ya que sus hijos salieron de la Universidad y trabajan ejerciendo su profesion, esta muy agradecido con Kiva y Emprender por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion dle credito.
texts.en:
Sr. Emilio is a service technician who repairs televisions, sound equipment, microwave ovens, computers, and all type of electronic devices. He is well-known in the district of San Antonio Bajo where he lives. Emilio is married and his wife has a restaurant that she manages on Saturdays. Both of them work to cover the household expenses and support one of their children since the others are already independent.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy spare parts. Emilio is a very responsible client and hard worker who is proud that his children succeeded in college and are now pursuing their professions. He is extremely grateful to Kiva and Emprender for demonstrating their confidence in him by providing this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare parts

loans.name: Kamran

texts.en:
Kamran is 28 years old and an internally displaced person from the city of Fuzuli. He is single and has been selling his wares for 5 years.  Currently, Kamran's work premises are small — 10 sq. meters.  He buys his goods at discount prices at Bine Trade Centre. 

Kamran is asking for a loan of 2000 AZN to update his merchandise. He hopes that having more (and newer) merchandise in his store will help him be more competitive. This would be his first loan.

loans.use: to update his merchandise

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana G. is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 52 years old. Luciana is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Luciana owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling cosmetics products in the local community. Luciana has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luciana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Luciana is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Luciana from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Adriana

texts.es:
Adriana tuvo 8 hijos, de los cuales 7 ya son independientes y uno esta estudiando en un instituto, y su mayor sueño es que su hijo culmine sus estudios y obtenga su titulo. Adriana viaja a las ferias en donde compra cereales que lego comercializa en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho, además Adriana tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende bebidas y gasolinas.
Adriana pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Palmeras y solicita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de trigo, cebada y bebidas. 
Adriana tiene como meta ampliar sus negocios.
texts.en:
Adriana had eight children, of whom seven are already independent and one is studying at an institue. Her greatest dream is that her son finishes his education and obtains his degree. Adriana travels to markets where she buys cereals that she then sells in the markets of the city of Ayacucho. In addition, Adriana has a shop in her house where she sells drinks and gasoline. Adriana belongs to the Las Palmeras Community Bank and she is requesting a loan of 800 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of wheat, barley and drinks. Adriana's goal is to expand her businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of wheat, barley and drinks.

loans.name: Rano

texts.en: Rano M. H. lives in the city of Lahore, Pakistan,  famous for its history and culture. She is an older working woman who does sewing  for her neighborhood clients. She has a lot of experience in embroidery and sewing  because she has been involved in this work for  last fifteen years. Her husband's name is M. H.. He is a butcher and runs a butcher shop in the market. He specifically sells chicken meat in his shop.  Rano has applied for a loan for her husband. With the loan her husband will buy the chickens and expand his chicken meat selling business. Rano loves her family and always ready to help in any way possible. She hopes that this investment will be successful for her husband’s business and he will be able to increase his income as well.

loans.use: To purchase chickens for her husband's butcher shop

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
Felicidad A. is from the village of Cabisera 5. She is 52 years old. Felicidad is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Felicidad owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Felicidad has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Felicidad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Felicidad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Felicidad is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Felicidad from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell

loans.name: Mwanandi

texts.en:
Mwanandi A. is a married woman with five grown children. She lives in her own house without electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She has been making money by weaving mats for the last five years. She sells them from her home to her neighbors and passersby, but she faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.

Mwanandi’s major goal working with Yehu is to get financial assistance to boost her business. With 10,000 KES she wants to open a retail shop and buy more weaving materials. She hopes to sell the mats wholesale in the future.

loans.use: To open a retail shop and buy more weaving materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Invest in her business (one wants to buy more video games for her business and the other to purchase cosmetics and perfumes to sell)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more dozens of slippers

loans.name: Diego

texts.en: Diego F. owns and operates a business providing transportation services. He is 52 years old, married and has two adult children. He is from Bañadero, Ozamiz City. Diego has been in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2004, Diego joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Diego has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Diego is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair his vehicle for better service. This will be his sixth loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a vehicle for better service

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mr. Sok P. is a 48-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Chhnang Province. He is married to Mrs. Thoun, age 38. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has given birth to three children, all of whom are single. 

He owns a big farm that he inherited from his grandmother. Currently, he wants to feed more pigs and he hopes to sell them to buyers four months after he begins raising them. To help solve this problem, he has requested a loan of $1100 that he will use to buy more pigs and sacks of pig feed to earn more profit.

Mr. Sok P. was not available, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and sacks of pig feed to earn more profits.

loans.name: Sop Sa Jëkër Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOP SA JËKËR est créé le 28 mars 2008. Il est composé de 09 femmes qui nouent des liens de parenté. Leur activité principal est petit commerce. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de MONTAGNE NORD2

Madame Fatou D., debout à droite de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 22 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants en charge.

Elle fait un petit commerce de produits divers. Tels des enfants et tissus et ustensile de cuisine

Avec son financement elle va augmenter son niveau d'approvisionnement pour accroitre ses bénéfices

Son objectif est de renforcer son niveau d'épargne et de participer à la prise en charge familiale.
texts.en:
The SOP SA JËKËR solidarity group was created March 28, 2008. It is composed of nine women with ties of kinship. As their main activity, they run small businesses. The group is part of the Banc Villageois MONTAGNE NORD2.

Mrs. Fatou D., standing on the right in the photo, is the group leader. She is 22 years old, married, and the mother of two children in her care. She sells various items such as fabrics and kitchen utensils. 

With her loan, she plans to increase her stocks of merchandise and bolster her profits. Her goal is to boost her savings and help take care of the family.

loans.use: To develop and promote her small business

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “GRANITO DE MOSTAZA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco  y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Maria ; ella tiene 49 años de edad ,separa y tiene 2 hijos; La socia tiene su negocio de movilidad escolar conjuntamente trabaja con su esposo siendo esta la actividad que ambos realizan y sacan a su familia adelante.

La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar un scaner para su computadora y también para comprar algunos accesorios para el carro. 

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Maria belongs to the Grain of Mustard village bank.  The bank is located in the Cusco district, of Cusco, Peru.

She is 49 years old, separated from her husband and has 2 children.  She runs a business providing transportation to students with her husband.  Together they support their family and help to carry them forward.

She is seeking a loan to buy a scanner for her computer and to buy some accessories for her car.

She is grateful to those who are helping her to achieve this dream and she promises to pay back her loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase a scanner for her computer and to buy some accessories for her car

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary T. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  Mary has a retail shop. She has been in this business for 10 years and she works 7 days out of every week.  Mary sells her products in a shop at retail. Mary has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jericans of cooking oil. The main business challenge(s) for Mary include transportation and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and to start selling at wholesale only.
